Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.A prolonged dry spell of weather in April allowed workers to make good progress on a new debris catch-pit at the roadside, repairs to hillside debris fences, and other measures to support landslip resilience above and below the A trunk road.The A remains open  hours a day with traffic lights helping to safely filter traffic past the ongoing construction work in the area during daylight hours.Convoying of traffic on the A continues during the evening and overnight period for safety reasons.Eddie Ross, BEAR Scotland#s north west representative, said: #The recent favourable weather at the Rest has allowed us to make good progress with the ongoing construction of the debris catch-pits and strengthening the debris fences above the road.#The A is currently operating well, with traffic signal control in place during daylight hours and alternate single-lane convoy being implemented during the evening and overnight periods for safety reasons, with no reported issues and minimal waiting times for motorists.#The Old Military Road remains on standby, ready to be utilised should conditions in the area deteriorate, meaning we can switch traffic to the alternative route quickly to minimise any disruption to journey times.#As ever, we#re working on a safety-first approach and will only operate the Awe#re certain it is safe for us to do so.#We thank all road users and the local community for their continued patience while we do everything we can to progress with the ongoing mitigation measures at the Rest.#

title: former-ross-high-pupil-ruari-paton-aiming-scottish-cup-glory
story: Ruari Paton will be hoping to line up for Stranraer todaywhen they make the long journey north to face Brora Rangers, who stunned Hearts in the previous round.The frontman attended the Tranent secondary school after signing for Hibernian as a teenager and making the move from Dublin.Many had expected Stranraer to be travelling to Tynecastle this weekend but Brora caused one of the biggest shocks in the competitionrsquos history when they won - last Tuesday.Paton was part of the Stranraer team taking on Brechin City at the same time and said that his reaction was much the same as football fans up and down the country when he heard the result.He said: ldquoI would not like to take anything away from Brora but you donrsquot really hear of a Championship team getting beaten by a Highland League or a Lowland League team ever.ldquoIt was a shock, it was a big shock, but fair play to them.ldquoWhat an achievement it is and it is an amazing challenge to overcome.ldquoYou cannot take anything away from them.Stranraer have enjoyed an impressive start to the campaign, with just one defeat since the beginning of November, as they look toto League One.Paton, who now lives in Bothwell, South Lanarkshire, has been at the heart of that form, scoring eight goals in all competitions, with strikes against Spartans and a last-minute penalty winner against Kelty Hearts in the previous round.He has also found the net for Gala Fairydean Rovers, while on loan from Hibs, and for East Kilbride in the competition last year.Now, attention has turned to the trip to Brora and Paton said: ldquoTherersquos nothing better in the world than scoring. Any forward player will tell you that. If you have a terrible game and score a goal or play fantastic and not score ndash you are judged on your goals as a forward.ldquoHopefully, I will get another goal but I need to make sure I am in the team. I would love another goal and I love the Scottish Cup. I loved it with East Kilbride and Gala Fairydean Rovers ndash it is great and you love those big moments in competitions.Paton moved from Dublin to East Lothian after signing for Hibs around his th birthday.He lived with Helen Leslie and her two sons, Darren and Jonathan, off Tranentrsquos Waterloo Road and attended Ross High School, where he studied physical education, English and sports leadership.The striker was quick to praise both the family and the school for helping him develop. He said: ldquoThey took me in asI was part of their family.ldquoThey were absolutely fantastic to me and made me feel so welcome.ldquoI went for dinner with them and they were brilliant.ldquoIn my first year, I spoke to Sean McPartlin, education and welfare officer, and he askedI wanted to do something. I agreed to it and they said I would train some days.ldquoIt is the best thing I ever did.That saw Paton ide his time between attending school and training at Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains on the outskirts of Ormiston.The -year-old spent two years at the secondary school and told Courier Sport how much he enjoyed the experience. He added: ldquoIt was brilliant ndash the best thing I ever did, honestly.ldquoI was not too keen going to school at that age with football andI had not then I would not have made many friends. The amount of people I met through school was unbelievable.Paul Reynolds, headteacher of the Tranent secondary school, said: ldquoNot only was Ruari a standout footballer, he was a true gentleman.ldquoHe was always extremely polite and his positive attitude was infectious. I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: prestonpans-b-m-says-no-tagging
story: East Lothian Licensing Board was asked by its licence standards officer to request BM stores introduce the tags after it applied for a licence to sell alcohol from its Prestonpans store.However during a virtual meeting of the board yesterday , BM representative Richard Williams urged members not to impose the condition.He said: "BM do not have tagging in this store. Since it opened we have not had any issue with theft and have not had any need to instal security tagging."Installing a tagging system will cost BM pound,.": BM opens in PrestopansThe store, which opened in the former Co-op store in March last year, said additional conditions including having CCTV set up to monitor the drinks aisle and agreeing to report any thefts to police were acceptable.Police Scotland did not object to the store being given an alcohol licence.The board heard one objection had been raised with the claimant, a personal licence holder, stating there was an overprovision of alcohol outlets in the area.However BM contested that view and pointed out that while the chain was a discount retailer it did not sell discounted alcohol.It added: "Price point for alcohol is generally higher than other major supermarket retailers."The board approved the alcohol licence without the need for tagging for The Links shopping centre store.

title: stone-snake-prestonpans-cockenzie-port-seton-moving-permanent-home
story: Dozens of members of the public put down stones as the snake stretched along Edinburgh Road between the town and neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton.Now, Prestonpans Community Council has secured land to ensure the snake lives on beyond coronavirus restrictions.Emma Orphant felt it was important that the stone work of art had a permanent place in the town.She said: ldquoOther than being a reminder of the pandemic, it has really brought families together.ldquoIt is another activity that families have been able to do, to get out and about, kids and grandparents.ldquoIrsquove certainly had my nephews down making the rocks and it is really a family thing.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, said that work would now need to take place before the snake moved to its new home off Edinburgh Road.She took to social media to encourage people to do their bit and said: ldquoIf you painted and placed a stone within the snake, and would like it to be forever within the memorial, thenyou could pop along and collect it and,it needs it, re-paint it, and nish it so that they are ready for when East Lothian Council have prepared the area and we are ready to set them into the concrete.ldquoPrestonpans Community Council has secured funding to purchase nish and are planning on having an open daywhere the nish will be available and you can finish off your stone.ldquoWe are looking for the stones to be collected from the wall no later than April , and any stones left after that date will be disposed of as they may become displaced when work starts on the old power station site and Greenhills.It is hoped the project will be complete within a matter of weeks.

title: children-organise-yard-sale-first-step-nursery-musselburgh
story: Honor Nicoll, aged  nine-year-old Fallyn Davie and Calli-Sophia Clark, aged eight, set up a stall on Moir Avenue, selling a iety of goods including books, unused toys, soft toys, bikes and scooters as well as crispy cakes.The funds raised will be donated to the First Step nursery on Galt Avenue.Penelope and Delilah Nunn and Carson Clark also helped with the sale and donations from local businesses and iniduals were also received.The children thanked everyone who supported them at the yard sale.

title: school-presents-special-medal-memory-kind-caring-pupil-aaron-passed-away-aged-11
story: Keen footballer Aaron Higgsreceived the Pope Francis Medal, which is presented annually to an exceptional P pupil at the townrsquos Loretto RC Primary School.Voted for by staff, the accolade is given to a kind and caring child.The school had closed amidst the first coronavirus lockdown last year, and -year-old Aaron was excited at moving onto secondary school.His dad Martin said his sonrsquos death in March  was ldquosudden and unexplained.He described the award as ldquoa celebration of his son and stood for everything he was.He added: ldquoIt sums up Aaron beautully.ldquoHe always tried to make everyone smile and was kind, loving and caring.ldquoHe always looked out for his friends.ldquoThe award symbolises everything Aaron was.ldquoIf anyone was feeling down, he would try to pick them up.Aaron loved football and played for Musselburgh Youngstars.He was also an avid fan of Nottingham Forest Football Club and Celtic Football Club.Due to the Covid- pandemic, Martin and Gemma, Aaronrsquos mum were unable to receive the award on their sonrsquos behalf.However, they have now able to attend at the school for the socially distanced presentation.The whole family, including Aaronrsquos brother Aiden, aged eight, and three-year-old sister Evie were proud of his achievement.Martin said: ldquoWe are so proud that Aaronrsquos amazing qualities have been recognised by others.Margaret Anne McBean, headteacher at Loretto RC Primary School, said: ldquoEach year, a P Loretto pupil is awarded the Pope Francis Medal.ldquoThe medal is awarded to the pupil who throughout their whole time in Loretto demonstrates our schoolrsquos Gospel values.ldquoAaron was the unanimous nomination last session for his love and kindness, politeness, respect for all and great effort in everything he did.ldquoWe are delighted at last, in a small but public way, to be able to celebrate the lovely boy he was and remember him.

title: giant-hole-appears-street-near-dunbars-east-beach
story: Sinkholes have appeared on the townrsquos Lamer Street in recent years, with the latest highlighted by the townrsquos community council.A spokeswoman for the group said: ldquoRecent heavy seas have caused a further undercutting and breach of the sea wall defences at Lamer Street.ldquoThis time, a sinkhole has appeared near Coastguard Cottages.ldquoAG Thompson have been on site to do emergency repairs ndash pumping cement into the void.ldquoMembers of Dunbar Shore and Harbour Neighbourhood Group East Beach Regeneration Group Dunbar Community Council will be meeting with East Lothian Council officers to discuss a longer-term masterplan and actions to improve the sea wall defences in the area.

title: driving-ban-musselburgh-man-caught-twice-drink-drive-limit
story: Stephen Baigan, of Stoneyhill Road, was breathalysed by police after being pulled over at Park Avenue, Edinburgh, on February  last year.The -year-old gave a reading of mg of alcohol in ml of breath. The legal limit is mg.Baigan admitted the offence at court on Monday.He was fined pound and banned from driving for  months.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-april-26-30-1996-1971-1921
story: A CELEBRITY backing an appeal was front page news in the East Lothian Courier on April , .TV naturalist Prof. David Bellamy has flown north to see threatened Pressmennan Wood for himself ndash and said he was ldquoamazed that the area itself was so little known before now.The celebrity conservationist was taken around the wood by local campaigners who had invited him to come and support their plea to stop the chop of around  ancient sessile oaks which would take out a third of the wood.Prof. Bellamy noted that the site was only five miles away from the birthplace of John Muir, the ldquofather of conservation who created national parks across the United States.He said: ldquoJohn Muir would turn in his grave.ldquoWersquore leaving Scotland to go bald and bare.Prof. Bellamy, who used to travel around the area regularly and has flown over the Lammermuirs at close range in a helicopter, was strongly opposed to plans to dispose of the tress.HADDINGTON was in need of a supermarket, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier on April , .The need for a greater choice of shops in Haddington was emphasised by Mrs Pauline Duffield, one of the local Labour Partyrsquos candidates in the coming municipal election, when she spoke at the annual Ratepayersrsquo Meeting in the Town House last week.More than  people attended the meeting at which the Councilrsquos achievements during the past  months and plans or the future were put under the microscope.Mrs Duffield, a newcomer to the municipal scene, said her main reason for deciding to stand for election was one of growing concern ndash a concern for the town of Haddington and concern for the people who lived in it.A TRAIN driver was injured at Haddington railway station while cleaning his train, told The Haddingtonshire Courier on April , .On Saturday, Mr Walter Bell, engine-driver, residing at Longniddry, sustained a serious accident while engaged cleaning the front of his locomotive at Haddington station.Missing his foothold near the top of the engine, he fell heavily upon the rail, his right thigh being fractured.It was decided to convey the injured man to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary by means of a van and engine specially run for the purpose.At Longniddry, Mrs Bell was taken on board, and accompanied her husband during the remainder of the journey.

title: tims-book-road-legends-chapter-12-healing-pool
story: IZZY knew she had to get Ewen out of the room, otherwise Finn was going to wake.She put her hand around one of his arms and tried to pull him towards the door.Eventually he responded, desperately trying to pull himself together for the sake of his son. Still unable to control his weeping, he began to crawl backwards. Izzy opened the door and cradled him as he crumpled onto the floor in the corridor outside the room.Izzy glanced quickly inside, checking Finn was still asleep. He moved for a moment, then turned over. She slowly and carefully closed the door and sat down with Ewen, putting her arms around him.She had no words, but knew words were not what was needed. She just held him in a hug as he wept his soul out.A fellow guest walked by on the way to the showers. He paused for a moment with a towel hanging over his right shoulder.ldquoYou all right  he asked.ldquoMy friend has just had some bad news, said Izzy.ldquoOK, yeah, I can see that, hope it works out, he said awkwardly and headed for the showers.Finally, Ewen began to compose himself and appeared from behind his hands, his face a sodden mess. Izzy took her arms away, gave him a sympathetic look and stood up.ldquoLetrsquos find a place we can sit and talk, she said.Ewen nodded and pulled himself up off the floor with Izzyrsquos help. When they entered the kitchen area, everyone instinctively moved away and left them alone. Ewen sat at a table and Izzy put the kettle on.Then she came and sat next to him, putting a supportive hand on his left arm. They both sat, not speaking. Ewen finally stopped crying and Izzy got up and brought some paper kitchen towels so he could wipe his face, then went to make tea for them both. She ed with two steaming mugs and sat by him again, still not speaking, just being there for him, her best friend.He stared at the mug of tea, lted it to his lips, then spoke before he drank.ldquoI hardly recognised him, he said.He took a gulp of tea and looked up at Izzy.His voice began to break as he tried to explain: ldquoItrsquos been four years since I saw him ndash last time was just before his eighth birthday. Hersquos changed so much. But then I heard his breathing as he slept, thatrsquos the same, I recognised that.He drank some more tea, took in a deep breath, then exhaled loudly with a sigh.ldquoHe used to fall asleep after Irsquod told him a story and I would stay for a while and listen to him breathe.He could feel tears welling up again. ldquoSorry Izzy, I canrsquot help it, so embarrassing.Tears streamed down his cheeks again and he lowered his head.Izzy walked to the sink, tore some more kitchen towels from the rack and gave them to him. She sat by him.ldquoI canrsquot imagine what it feels like, Ewen, all those years of pent-up emotion missing your son, there is no need to apologise. I should have realised how hard that would be for you. It was my mistake.Ewen looked up. ldquoGod no, Izzy, thanks to you Irsquove seen Finn, close up, in the moonlight and sleeping. I was able to whisper to him under my breath that I loved him, just before I lost it and made that scene.Izzy looked round the empty kitchen.ldquoI think everyone in here thinks wersquore a couple whorsquove fallen out, she said. ldquoIrsquom a bit concerned that people will talk about it tomorrow morning and Finn could overhear. I think, to be on the safe side, we will leave as soon as possible and have breakfast by the loch. At least then you will get to see him in the morning in the way wersquove arranged.ldquoYeah, thatrsquod be great. Irsquove pitched the tent in the hidden spot in the trees, Irsquoll keep an ear out for you arriving.Ewen realised he was hungry.ldquoYou havenrsquot got something to eat, have you  he asked. ldquoIrsquove not eaten since lunchtime just not been hungry, till now.Izzy gave him a packet of crisps: ldquoSorry thatrsquos all I have to hand.ldquoNo, thatrsquos perfect, thanks, I just need a snack. Irsquoll cook something by the loch later.He opened the packet, then scrunched the crisps into small bits. Izzy watched as he tipped them into his mouth and carefully folded the empty packet into a small square.ldquoFinn does exactly that when he eats crisps, she said.ldquoWersquod have a competition, explained Ewen, ldquoto see who could fold the packet into the smallest square. It was just one of the things we used to do. I dunno how we started it. I think the idea is you canrsquot fold anything more than seven times, so we would try to.ldquoWell, he still does it.Ewen smiled but it was a sad one. Izzy wasnrsquot sureshe was making things worse or better for him by telling him such things.ldquoDoes he like his boots  he asked.ldquoLoves them and they fit perfectly.Ewen nodded, then clenched his hands together on the table. Izzy could feel his pain. She placed her hands on top of his.ldquoEwen, you are doing amazing, this must be hell for you, I know how much you love Finn and want him to know it. But please, be careful. He could have seen you at the Falls of Leny, and he definitely saw you talking to me at Balquhidder. Hersquos seen your car. We have to be super careful to ensure he doesnrsquot recognise you or realise.Ewen nodded: ldquoSally comes up with a dferent hire car tomorrow, so that should make things less obvious. I think shersquos worried about me.ldquoMe too, you be OK tonight  asked Izzy.ldquoIrsquoll be OK. This evening, even though it was for a brief moment and he didnrsquot know it, I was with Finn. Irsquoll know hersquos near and will have a distant view of him in the morning. I feel closer to him than I have for four years, although itrsquos making me feel like a stalker.ldquoYoursquore not a stalker, Ewen, yoursquore a dad who loves his son.Ewen clenched his hands again. ldquoThank you.ldquoIrsquom doing it for Finn as much as for you, said Izzy. She was still sure she was doing the right thing, but was terried of the risks.ldquoPlease remember to be careful and stick to the plans we made, she pleaded. ldquoWe have to keep him safe. Hersquos been through enough already.ldquoI will, I promise.Ewen finished his tea and left the hostel.Izzy sat a while, trying to calm herself, eyes closed and breathing deeply.ldquoYou all right, honey She opened her eyes: it was a woman who had come into the kitchen. Izzy wanted to say yes but the womanrsquos concern and kind words triggered a flood of tears. It was her turn to be comforted, by a stranger who knew nothing of the burden she carried, of her guilt and overwhelming feeling of responsibility.ldquoThank you for being so kind, she said to the woman. ldquoI feel much better now after a wee greet.ldquoNo man is worth such upset, my lovely, the kind woman said. Izzy just nodded and smiled at her. If only it was that simple, she thought.She ed to the room and opened the door slowly Finn was sound asleep. Izzy felt emotionally exhausted and hoped shersquod fall asleep quickly, but as she lay in her bed after a hot shower, she couldnrsquot stop her mind racing it had been so close, whatFinn had woken  She trusted Ewen to be careful. But she must be careful too. Finally, under the gaze of MacFarlanersquos Lantern, sleep overtook her.Finn was first to wake in the morning.ldquoAunty, aunty, itrsquos morning! he said while looking out of the window. It was daylight but the sky had clouded over and thick mist hung on the hills.ldquoA typical Highland morning, he said cheerfully.Izzy got things packed as Finn had his shower and they left the hostel before most of the other residents were out of their beds. After a phone call to Finnrsquos mum, they set off.ldquoWhere we having breakfast  asked Finn.ldquoVery close by, on the banks of Loch Dochart.They drove for just a few minutes and pulled into a layby. Izzy performed her usual routine of bringing her rucksack. They walked through some woodland and arrived at the waterrsquos edge.ldquoWow, is that an island with a castle on it  asked Finn.ldquoIt is, said Izzy, ldquoand what stories are here! Irsquoll tell you some over breakfast.Finn helped Izzy set up her stove and they took turns stirring the porridge. There were midges in the air, at times annoying, but it was late in the season and their biting was minimal. A breeze from the loch kept them away most of the time.She told Finn of the castlersquos history, how the island was once a MacGregor stronghold, but that lsquoBlack Duncan Campbellrsquo built the castle they saw now after he took the land.Then Izzy told an ancient legend: ldquoIt was here that Fionn MacCoul met his death, at the hands of a giant named Taileachd.Finn scooped more porridge into his bowl but he nodded, showing he was listening and wanted Izzy to continue.ldquoThe giant lived with his sweetheart, who was a beautul faery maiden.ldquoOf course, said Finn, smiling cheekily.Izzy ed the smile and continued: ldquoSome versions of the tale say they had their home on an island on Loch Lubhair, just downstream, while others an island here on Loch Dochart, maybe even that one.Finn studied the castlersquos ruins, which peered out from the trees which covered the island. It looked so mysterious.ldquoOne day, Taileachd discovered that his sweetheart had met Fionn and they had fallen in love.ldquoSo Fionn ran off with her, thatrsquos ironic! laughed Finn.ldquoNo, you see she loved them both, maybe in dferent ways, but she was now torn between them. They were going to fight over her, and she knew one of them would be killed, so she came up with an idea.Finn put his bowl down and listened as Izzy acted out the tale.ldquolsquoPlease put your anger awayrsquo, said the faery woman. lsquoI love you both, but whoever can leap the furthest I shall be with.rsquoldquoA jumping competition! exclaimed Finn.ldquoExactly!Izzy dramatically described how the two competitors leapt from the island trying to outperform each other. They were equally matched but when they jumped backwards, Fionn momentarily lost his balance and the giant, fearful he was going to lose his sweetheart, took the opportunity to cut off Fionnrsquos head!ldquoAw, ouch, foul! cried Finn.Izzy nodded and spoke with a solemn tone.ldquoIn that moment of violence, they all lost everything. The faery woman fled: she no longer loved Taileachd because of his brutal act, and Fionn, whom she loved, had lost his le. His body floated down the river, and was found by the Fiann, his band of warriors. They buried him at Killin and now they were full of vengeance, so went to search for Fionnrsquos murderer.ldquoDid they find him ldquoWell, Taileachd fled to Rannoch Moor and Irsquoll tell you what happened when we get there, later today.ldquoAw, aunty!Finnrsquos protest was interrupted as his attention was suddenly caught by the sight of a man in a dinghy rowing out into the loch. They watched as he struggled a bit in the current, then vanished behind the eastern side of the island. A few minutes later, the man appeared on top of the ruined tower, half hidden by branches. He sat there.Finn waved and the man waved back.ldquoI really want to go onto that island and see the castle and where the giant lived. Maybe that man will lend us his dingy ldquoHersquos probably going fishing, Finn, and is just looking at the water to see where the fish are. Hersquoll be there all day.ldquoWe could swim ldquoThe current is too strong here Finn, but we could swim at out next stop: St Fillanrsquos healing pool, itrsquos part of the river, just upstream from here.Finn stood by the waterrsquos edge looking out to the island, disappointed. But he accepted his auntrsquos decision.They packed up and headed for the healing pool. Ewen watched them go from his vantage point atop the ruins on the island.Here are the links to chapters one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine,  and .

title: letter-week-deeply-saddened-heavily-restricted-parking-hopes-estate
story: I was looking forward to walking up there with my children now that work has completed on the new car park, so I am deeply saddened by the behaviour of landowner Robbie Douglas-Miller.I genuinely hoped he was planning on improving parking so that more people could enjoy the terric walks in the area, but limiting access to  permit holders a month seems like an attempt at turning a public road into a private one.The residents of Hopes Estate will always be welcome to use the public roads in our towns to park, shop and visit as they please. It seems very unfair that we should no longer be able to use a road that we pay for to access the hills.I noticed a picture on Facebook, taken on a sunny Sunday when people would normally be out enjoying a walk around the reservoir, but only one car seems to be using the car park.As East Lothian grows, we should be utilising as much of our outdoor space as possible to help our population exercise and take pressure off coastlines and popular woodland areas. The Lammermuir Hills are underused for recreation and have a superb network of paths, but woefully inadequate parking.Overriding everything in the letter you printed is the Scottish Governments Land Reform Act of , which clearly states the Right for Responsible Access in Scotland.. The overall framework of land rights, responsibilities and public policies should promote, fulfil and respect relevant human rights in relation to land, contribute to public interest and wellbeing, and balance public and private interests. The framework should support sustainable economic development, protect and enhance the environment, help achieve social justice and build a fairer society.. There should be a more erse pattern of land ownership and tenure, with more opportunities for citizens to own, lease and have access to land.The landownerrsquos decision to heavily restrict parking prejudices families, those with disabilities and groups who take people walking in the hills and need an access point. I understand that during the last year, the countryside has suffered littering, fires and irresponsible parking, but to punish responsible visitors because of the behaviour of a minority is a knee-jerk reaction and will only create animosity towards the estate at a time when public opinion is turning against grouse shooting. Instead, the landowner should be working with local residents, East Lothian Council and interested parties to help improve access and educate visitors on how to visit responsibly.Name and address supplied

title: builders-merchant-built-instead-hotel-former-raceland-site
story: The former Raceland karting site, between Gladsmuir and Longniddry, closed in early .Work is due to start later this year on a petrol station, two drive-thru restaurants and a drive-thru cafe on the southern section of the site.Initial proposals suggested a hotel could be built on the northern part of the former karting site, where the outdoor track was located, but that could now be ditched for a buildersrsquo merchants.The karting centre was given planning permission in  and also operated a paintball centre. However, the business closed three years ago and Monte Blackburn Ltd bought the site.Now, the Blackburn-based owners want a buildersrsquo merchant to be based there, with MKM Building Supplies, which previously planned to move to Gateside in Haddington before opting against the switch ldquodue to the perceived impact on the surrounding residential area, earmarked as the occupier.A childrenrsquos nursery and care home could now be built on the Haddington Gateside site, with a planning application being weighed up by East Lothian Council.The developer behind the proposed buildersrsquo merchants acknowledged that there had been ldquoa long-standing requirement for a site in East Lothian for several years.A search of Tranent, Macmerry and Haddington was undertaken in a bid to find a suitable site for the business.An application for the Gladsmuir site is now with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.A planning statement which was included within the application said: ldquoPlanning permission is sought for the erection of a building for use as a buildersrsquo merchants.ldquoIf planning permission is granted, the end occupier will be MKM Building Supplies, a national company with approximately  stores throughout the UK.ldquoMKM Building Supplies is a Hull-based company, established in , and is the largest independent buildersrsquo merchant. In Scotland there are a total of  MKM branches, with the nearest branch to the application site being in central Edinburgh .A ldquowarehouse-style building, about eight metres high, would be created on the site. Outside would be ldquoa large hard-surfaced service yard storage area, with the site surrounding by fencing.The planning statement suggests about  new jobs would be created.In September last year, McDonaldrsquos was given permission for ious signs highlighting a potential restaurant on the site. Drawings suggested Greggs, Subway, Starbucks and KFC could join them at the former go-kart track site, although East Lothian Council stressed that the businesses listed in the image could change.Last year, a spokeswoman for KFC told the Courier: ldquoWersquoll be winging our way to East Lothian early next year ndash watch this space!It is anticipated that the roadside services development will commence later this year.

title: final-approval-given-80-new-homes-edge-elphinstone
story: Eighty new homes to the west of the village were approved by members of the local authorityrsquos planning committee in December .Now, the plans have been signed off by the planning department, with ious technicalities ironed out.The scheme, which will be built between Tranent Road and the villagersquos football pitch, will see  new houses built alongside four flats.Highland Residential Developments Ltdrsquos proposals were unanimously approved by the planning committee a week before Christmas in .At that time, Labour councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell and John McMillan were among those backing the plans.Twenty affordable homes will be built on the site, with East Lothian Council receiving pound, towards the provision of additional accommodation at the villagersquos primary school and Tranentrsquos Ross High School.A further pound, will go towards the refurbishment of the playing fieldrsquos changing pavilion, with more than a dozen parking spaces created within the development for people using the pitch, and nearly pound, will go towards play equipment in the park.The development will be accessed off the B, which passed through the heart of the village.All of the properties are two-storeys, with the housing split into  detached,  semi-detached and  terraced homes.The majority of the properties ndash  ndash will contain three bedrooms, with  containing two bedrooms and  containing four bedrooms.Each of the four flats will include two bedrooms.The development did not win favour with all residents though, with  objections to the proposals.Concerns included the number of houses was ldquocompletely out of character with the village setting while other fears included that the expansion of Tranent and Elphinstone was ldquodestroying the character of these settlements.

title: another-149-homes-planned-new-development-wallyford
story: Taylor Wimpey East Scotland has submitted an Approval of Matters specied in Conditionsapplication to East Lothian Council for the houses, which would be built on land at Futures Way.Forming part of the St Clements Wells masterplan, the company aims to build  new homes in a mix of two, three and four-bedroom properties at its Ravensheugh site in addition to its  homes already under construction.The developer also has plans to apply to build  to  more homes at a future point.Developer contributions from the overall St Clements Wells project are being made towards a new primary school, secondary school, local centre and community woodland, as well as the provision of new footpaths and cycleways to connect the development to Wallyford and the local train station.The total number of new homes approved for the Wallyford area ndash at St Clements Wells and the adjacent Dolphingstone site ndash is about ,.

title: new-bus-lane-relocated-bus-stops-centre-musselburgh-bid-ease-congestion
story: The existing bus stop outside the police station, for local westbound buses, has a lsquoKeep Clearrsquo road marking and a new bus lane on the approach to the stop, potentially operating Monday-Friday, am-pm.A new bus stop has been created westbound at Costa for buses to Edinburgh.Eastbound, the existing bus stop outside Musselburgh Citizens Advice Bureau is for coastal destinations, while a new stop at BrightHouse is for lsquoinlandrsquo buses to destinations such as Wallyford, Tranent and Haddington.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said that the work had been completed except for the erection of the bus shelters, which are not currently in stock and will be installed towards the end of May.She added: ldquoLothian Buses will have staff available on site to assist passengers with the changes.The new measures, funded by the Scottish Government, are temporary for an -month period, and traffic flow, including the times of bus journeys, will be monitored to assess the impact of the changes.The proposals are fully supported by the bus companies and it is hoped the reduced congestion will provide greater reliability of services.The council spokeswoman previously explained that congestion could happen on Musselburgh High Street when one bus had to wait in the carriageway while another was taking on passengers.Relocation and two additional bus stops aim to increase options for passengers, and a bus lane will deter double-parking on the approach to the police station bus stop, leaving sufficient room for vehicles to pass stationary buses.About  parking spaces needed to be removed and the Blue Badge parking space relocated across the road, but the existing taxi rank was unaffected by the changes.The total cost of the project, including detailed design and construction, is pound,, which comes from Transport Scotland via Bus Priority Rapid Deployment Fund.Ward councillor John Williamson said: ldquoThe test will be as lockdown eases and buses become busier, and therefore take longer to load and unload passengers at the bus stops.ldquoAs the measures are temporary, I would hope that it will be possible to tweak the measures in the light of experience.

title: yachts-craned-back-north-berwick-harbour-summer
story: Every winter, the boats are lted out of the water and put into storage.But last Friday and ahead of the upcoming sailing season, East Lothian Yacht Club arranged for  yachts to be lted from dry land by crane and lowered into the water at the harbour.The boats were lted onto a flat, wheeled tray and pushed or pulled to the water side, where the crane was waiting to lt them into the water, as these images by Derek Braid show.

title: scottish-tourism-sites-reopen-level-3-lockdown-rules
story: The good news is that, as of today,% of Historic Environment Scotlandrsquos sites will be open up to the public, including ticketed and over  free to access sites.Further ticketed sites are due to reopen on a rolling basis over the upcoming months.This includes some of Scotlandrsquos most iconic heritage sites including Edinburgh Castle,Stirling Castle, Linlithgow Palace, Urquhart Castle, St Andrews Castle, and Melrose Abbey.Visitors will be expected to wearface coverings in indoor spaces and some enclosed spaces, where social distancing cannotbe easily maintained, not accessible.There will also be initial capacity management on numbers, one-way systems will be in place in some locations, and visitors being asked to use contactless payment where possible.Tickets should be booked online in advance from the HES website.To book tickets and for more information on further HES sites reopening visit: restarthistory.scotAlex Paterson, Chief Executive of HES, said: "Our heritage sites are home to over , years of history and we canrsquot wait to welcome visitors back once more, so they can once again experience Scotlandrsquos history."As before, there will be measures in place to facilitate social distancing, as well as new innovations to the visitor experience including new audio tours and digital content."We know how much people enjoy being able to access heritage sites, and wersquove worked hard to provide a mix of sites across the country, with over % of our sites opening up on the th and many others on a phased basis over the next few months."On the eve of what is a historic reopening, itrsquos been great to be at the castle to see all the hard work of the teams coming to fruition as we get ready to welcome visitors once more.

title: 11-best-outdoor-activities-families-scotland
story: This means that shops, restaurants, and cafes will all be reopened, and along with an easing of travel restrictions, it means that families can go and explore the great outdoors over the May Bank Holiday weekend.So, to celebrate the easing of restrictions, Fiona Russell gives usguide to the best of outdoor fun for families in Scotland.. Stand Up PaddleboardingSUP for short is a fast-growing outdoor activity and is ideal for all the family. You need to be able to swim but apart from that, the large and stable board, plus buoyancy aid for safety, allows people of all ages to paddle while standing up on calm waters.SUPs can be hired on Loch Lomond, which is the UKrsquos largest area of inland freshwater, as well as on the Isle of Arran, and Loch Morlich, near Aviemore.. CanyoningThis is another adrenalin-fuelled activity that sees participantsdescending a series of waterfalls and pools by jumping, sliding, crawling, climbing, swimming and repelling.The Falls of Bruar in Perthshire are famous for canyoning potential, as well as Tummel and Dollar canyons. Activity providers kit you out in wetsuit, buoyancy aid and helmet, and then lead the way.For a tamer alternative, try gorge walking in locations with easier descents and gentler river flow.. Mountain bikingHire a mountain bike at one of Scotlandrsquos many trail centres and ride routes that are graded green for beginners, through blue, red and black for the most experienced. There are also orange grades for the most technical downhill sections.Visit trail centres such as Glentress near Peebles Laggan Wolftrax near Newtonmore and Comrie Croft in Perthshire, where there are routes for all ages and aspirations.. Canadian canoeingThere are numerous rivers and lochs in Scotland that are ideal for a two-person paddle in an open-top Canadian canoe.To start with, choose a calm day and a waterway that is not choppy. There are plenty of providers that hire Canadian canoes, or you could join a guided trip in locations such as the Great Glen Canoe Trail, the River Spey or Loch Sunart, on the Ardnamurchan peninsula.:Staycation Scotland:  picturesque farm stays to visit this year. BMX ridingLearn how to ride a BMX bike on a purpose-built off-road racetrack. The track usually comprises a groomed dirt racecourse that looks a bit like a serpentine with jumps, rollers and berms.The small-sized bikes, which are suitable for children and adults, require you to stand up on the pedals to ride.Itrsquos a lot harder than it looks but also fun. Glasgow BMX Centre is Scotlandrsquos only world and Olympic standard BMX track. You can book taster sessions.. Smartphone orienteeringOrienteering is an great adventure sport for families and one that that exercises the body and mind. The aim is to navigate between checkpoints or controls marked on a special orienteering map.Permanent courses set up by Scottish Orienteering can now be used with the phone app MapRun.The only dference from a ldquotraditional course is that there are no physical markers on the ground. Instead, the phone tracks your location as you run and vibrates to confirm when yoursquove reached each control point.. Walk with an alpacaAn emerging trend in the outdoors activity world, especially for families with young children, is going for a walk with alpacas. The animals are a domesticated species from South America and very friendly.There are many places now offering walks and treks with alpacas, such as East Lothian, in the Pentlands near Edinburgh, Moray, Fe and on the Solway Coast in Dumfries  Galloway.. WindsurfingWindsurfing combines surfing and sailing in one activity and can be enjoyed on the sea or inland lochs.Since Scotland has plentul wind and water, there are many places to try windsurfing although it is a good idea to take a few lessons first.Some great destinations include the isles of Tiree and Lewis, as well as Loch Ken, in Dumfries  Galloway, and Loch Insh in the Highlands.. Horse ridingRiding a horse or pony as part of a led trek offers a wonderful way to view the landscape. From a horsersquos back, yoursquoll enjoy a new perspective and have the chance to bond with a friendly animal.Many riding fans say they find a special mental calmness from the activity, as well as a physical workout.There are numerous stables that can cater for all riding abilities, or you could join an overnight glamping trip with Highland ponies in the Cairngorms.. Whitewater raftingWhitewater rafting is for the more adventurous family and offers a wet and wild experience. Take a thrilling journey down stunning fast-flowing rivers, drops and rapids, guided by an experienced rafter.There are rafting providers that operate on the rivers Findhorn and Tummel in the Cairngorms the River Tay in Perthshire and the River Garry, near Fort William, among others.. Climb treesJoin a tree-climbing adventure and see the natural world from a new perspective. There are activity centres with permanent tree adventure courses where you climb, swing and zipline above the forest floor.Alternatively, families can join a tree-climbing experience using specialist equipment.

title: rosyth-military-exercise-feature-forth-usa-germany-france-taking-part
story: One of the largest military exercises of its kind in Europe, Strike Warrior  which incorporates Exercise Joint Warrior -, will run from May  to  with a few of the participating vessels departing from ports on the East Coast of Scotland.For this exercise, port visits will be kept to a minimum, however vessels are expected to arrive at Rosyth and Leith before joining the exercise.Joint Warrior - is integrated with Exercise Strike Warrior  as part of the final preparations for the first deployment of the UKrsquos Carrier Strike Groupnext month. HMS Queen Elizabeth, theRoyalNavyrsquos Fleet Flagship sits at the centre of the CSG which will deploy shortly after the completion of Strike Warrior.Ten nations,will take part, bringing  warships, three submarines,  aircraft and approximately , military personnel including , ground troops to military ranges across the country and to maritime exercise areas off the North and West Coasts of Scotland.The participating NATO nations will be the UK, USA, Denmark, France, Germany, Latvia, The Netherlands, Norway, Poland Australia is the non-NATO participant.Joint Warriorand Strike Warrior are designed, planned and delivered by the Joint Tactical Exercise Planning Staffbased at Northwood in London, some of which will deploy to HM Naval Base Clyde to coordinate events during the Exercise.Exercise activity will include:Thirty-four naval units from Australia, Denmark, France, Germany, Latvia, The Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, the UK and the USA participating around the Scottish Coast.Mine Counter measures operations in areas around Campbelltown and Loch Ewe.A total of  aircraft will take part in the exercise with some of them operating from RAF Lossiemouth, Prestwick Airportand Stornoway Airport.Joint Firing Activity will take place at Cape Wrath Weapons Range, Garvie Island and the QinetiQ Hebrides range in the North of Scotland.Exercise activity in the North Minch to the west of Ullapool involving fast small boats, both civilian and military.GPS denial operations off the West coast of Scotland. The operations will be conducted at limited periods each day and the relevant authorities, especially maritime and aviation, have been involved in the planning process and relevant safeguards have been put in place.Exercise Joint Warrior or Strike Warrior as it is known for this time only, is linked directly with the NATO Military Training Exercise Programme and brings together all three UK Armed Forces ndash theRoyalNavy, Army andRoyalAir force ndash along with the other participating countries, to provide high quality training opportunities and improve joint operations between the UK and its allies.Participants will practice a wide range of capabilities across land, sea and air in coordinated joint operations with other allied nations, with the Carrier Strike Group being a key element on this occasion prior to the deployment of the HMS Queen Elizabeth Task Group.The scenario of the exercise will mirror a broad range of crisis and conflict situations which could realistically be experienced in real-world operations.Over the fortnight, participants will be faced with a period of increasing political and military tensions, along with a huge range of realistic military tasks such as: intelligence gathering and reconnaissance anti-smuggling and counter-terrorism operations humanitarian assistance and evacuation operations.All units involved in the exercise will observe Covid  control measures, such as a general requirement for -day quarantine periods before personnel can embark in the ships of the UK Carrier Strike Group. In addition, there will only be limited port visits by UK and allied units and then only for operational and logistical reasons.Exercise planning staff have liaised with a wide iety of communities and organisations ahead of Strike Warrior in order to minimise the impact of military activity. Organisations consulted include: The Civil Aviation AuthorityNational Air Traffic ServicesThe Highlands and Islands Airports Authority Scottish and Northern Irish fishery organisations and several environmental agencies and groups.Further information on Exercise Strike Warrior, includingnotices to mariners and impact statements,can be found by visiting Queenrsquos Harbour Master Clydersquos page on theRoyalNavywebsite:Joint Warriors and other exercises |RoyalNavy

title: gangmasters-agency-targets-haddington-home
story: Community officers were joined by colleagues from East Lothian Council and the GLAA at the home on Wednesday, in an operation described to the Courier by one eye witness as a ldquoraid.A spokesperson for Police Scotland said: ldquoThe purpose of these visits was to check on the welfare and living conditions of local farm and factory workers. All were safe and well and all was in order."We will continue working with partners to provide safe living and working conditions for workers who support local industry.A spokeswoman from East Lothian Council added: ldquoFollowing a request from the GLAA, representatives from the councilrsquos licensing and environmental health teams attended properties in Haddington High Street to ensure appropriate standards of property and living conditions were in place for tenants.The GLAA is a national enforcement agency whose role is to protect workers from labour exploitation.It investigates reports of unlicensed trading, worker exploitation and illegal labour provision, as well as offences under the National Minimum Wage and Employment Agencies Acts.

title: dates-confirmed-reopening-six-east-lothians-libraries---two-reopen-monday
story: Libraries in East Lothianrsquos six towns are the only ones scheduled to reopen at this stage.Both Haddington and Musselburgh libraries are gearing up to open for the first time this year and are the first branches in the county to do so.Both open at am on Monday and customers will be allowed to enter the buildings on a strict quota system. They will also be asked to follow a one-way route around the library.They will both be open Mondays-Fridays, am-pm and -.pm.Haddington Library is found within the John Gray Centre.From next Monday , Prestonpans and Dunbar libraries will re-open with similar arrangements in place. A limited number of people will be allowed in the buildings at any one time and a one-way route will be in place at both venues.Dunbar Library will be open Mondays-Fridays, am-pm and -pm.Prestonpans Library will be open Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays, also am-pm and -pm.The following week is when North Berwick and Tranent libraries will reopen, on May .North Berwick Library will be open Mondays-Fridays, am-pm and -pm.Tranent Library will be open Mondays-Thursdays, alsoam-pm and -pm.It has not yet been announced when libraries in villages in East Lothian will reopen.Sharon Saunders, head of community services at East Lothian Council, said: ldquoA lot of preparation work has been required to ensure the safe reopening of our public libraries for both staff and customers, and wersquore delighted that our branches are able to welcome people back.ldquoEast Lothian Council has previously enjoyed support from both Midlothian and Scottish Borders Councils for use of mobile library services in some of our rural communities across the county and we hope to shortly confirm when these will be available to residents in Ormiston, Whitecraig, Macmerry, Gford, Pencaitland, East Saltoun and Humbie.

title: scotland-10-cool-quirky-places-stay
story: Applecross Campsite, Applecross, Wester RossThe mighty Bealach na Ba and spectacular views over Applecross Bay are right on your doorstep. In line with Scottish Government guidelines, the campsite is open to self-contained vehicles and static caravans only from Monday. Toilets and showers will remain closed.Call   or visit visitapplecrossBealach na Ba on the Applecross peninsula in Wester Ross. Picture: iStockphoto PACraighead Howfs, near Dunblane, PerthshireTwo Hobbit hole-style Howfs ndash the Burrow and Bagend ndash are built into the hillside with wildflower-strewn roofs and round doors for a magical glamping experience. New for  is the Whisky Howf, a quirky, squint-roofed cottage nestled beside a lochan.Call   or visit craigheadhowfCraighead Howfs, near Dunblane, PerthshireToravaig House, Sleat, SkyeThis nine-bedroom hotel is a cosy and sumptuous gem with views over the Sound of Sleat and nearby Torabhaig Distillery. Its lures include open fires and a baby grand piano in the lounge, as well as a restaurant showcasing the best of Skyersquos larder.Call   or visit skyehotel toravaig:Scotland Reopens:  charming farm shops, independent boutiques and bookstoresSleeperzzz, Rogart, SutherlandA great base for exploring Dunrobin Castle and the North Coast , Sleeperzzz is located beside a ing train station at Rogart . Accommodation includes a vintage railway carriage and a -ton goods van from the s.Call   or visit sleeperzzzSleeperzzz, Rogart, SutherlandHarvest Moon, near Dunbar, East LothianBeach strolls, rock pooling, woodland walks, sand dune sledging and sea swimming are a few of the delights on this picturesque site. The accommodation includes a mix of cabins and treehouses.Visit harvestmoonholidaysThe Sawmill at Glen Dye, Banchory, AberdeenshireA sleek, refurbished s Airstream Safari caravan in a small pine wood beside the fast flowing lade of a sawmill. Glen Dye also offers a river cabin, a bothy and two steading cottages.Call   or visit glendyecabinsandcottagesThe Sawmill at Glen Dye, Banchory, AberdeenshireHelicopter Glamping, Mains Farm Wigwams, Thornhill, StirlingStay in a Sea King helicopter with mini kitchen, bathroom and a cockpit seating area offering glorious views over the Forth Valley. The helicopter ndash part of Mains Farm Wigwams ndash sleeps two adults or a family of five.Call   or visit mainsfarmwigwams:Scotland Reopens:  charming farm shops, independent boutiques and bookstoresRoulotte Retreat, near Melrose, Scottish BordersA circle of seven colourful roulottessit in a pretty wildflower meadow below the Eildon Hills. Facilities include sunset decks, wood-burning stoves, eco saunas and hot tubs. Each roulotte faces on to a lochan at the centre of the site.Call   or visit roulotteretreatRoulotte Retreat, near Melrose, Scottish BordersEagle Brae, Struy, near Beauly, Inverness-shireA wildle adventure and eco escape await at Eagle Brae, a luxurious log cabin village on a tranquil hillside between Glen Affric and Glen Strathfarrar. Deer, pine martens and birdle will thrill nature lovers.Call   or visit eaglebraeEagle Brae, Struy, near Beauly, Inverness-shireMarthrown of Mabie, Mabie Forest, Dumfries and GallowayChoose from a yurt, tipi or Celtic roundhouse . Among the facilities are a barbecue area and a ropes challenge course.Call   or visit marthrownofmabie

title: six-scotlands-scenic-beer-gardens
story: .The PierhousePort Appin, Loch LinnheTucked away on the shores of Loch Linnhe, The Pierhouse boasts sweeping views across to the Isles of Lismore and Mull.The charming original building dates backto the th century when it was a stopping-off point for steam vessels travelling between Oban and Fort William. Now a small hotel and seafood restaurant, its menus include Argyll langoustines and mussels, alongside oysters from Loch Creran. Take a seat on the terrace or find a place on the newly-created outdoor decking area for dinner and drinks this summer.Watch the ferry cross the tranquil loch, set against the hills of Morvern and Ballachulish, with Ben Nevis to the north.pierhousehotel. Cold Town HouseGrassmarket, EdinburghThe microbrewery headquarters of Cold Town Beer occupies the former site of the Robertson Memorial Church at Grassmarket. The name takes inspiration from the old Calton Hill Brewery in Edinburgh ndash the first to brew lager in the UK in .Alongside craft ales and pilsners, you will find Neopolitan pizza and bottles of prosecco. The main attraction is a roof terrace dominated by the sight of Edinburgh Castle looming above. Book your spot and place your order at the converted vintage Citroeumln van in this lofty beer garden.coldtownhouse. The TaybankDunkeldSituated along the edge of the River Tay in Dunkeld is local landmark The Taybank ndash a pub, restaurant, cocktail bar, hotel, and beer garden.The white hotel is hard to miss and boasts one of the largest and most popular beer gardens in Perthshire. With large overhead tents, spacious picnic tables, fire pits, and a public car park directly beside the beer garden, itrsquos a firm favourite for both locals and tourists alike.The Taybank is no stranger to annual events including regular craft markets, live music and small festivals. Soaking in the atmosphere as the River Tay flows gently by in the summer sunshine is sheer bliss. The Taybank will be open from April  and tables will be appointed on a first-come, first-served basis.thetaybank. Badachro InnGairlochPositioned over the beautul Badachro Bay, and with an extensive list of guest ales, over  ieties of malt whisky and a fine selection of wine, the Badachro Inn by Gairloch ticks all the boxes.The inn, restaurant and bar utilise the rural serene location to great effect, thanks to an outside decking area on the banks of the bay. Visitors and locals can enjoy a meal and drink outside while appreciating the view of the bay sailing boats, lush green countryside and nearby working jetty.During lockdown, Badachro ersied by converting a Rice trailer horsebox into a wood-fired pizza oven, which guests can enjoy over the summer. Badachro Inn will be open for the season from May  and advanced booking is strongly advised ndash the inn is also family and pet friendly.badachroinn: of the best outdoor activities for families in Scotland. The Ship InnElie, FeWe could hardly compile a list of scenic beer gardens without mentioning The Ship Inn at Elie.One of the most popular pubs in the picturesque East Neuk of Fe, The Ship Inn is renowned for its seaside outdoor seating area, offering a wonderful panorama over the expanse of Elie beach.Cricket fans will enjoy the opportunity to watch the pubrsquos very own cricket team play on the sand during the summer while the gastropub menu proves a hit with even the fussiest of eaters. A must-visityou are in the area.shipinn.scot. The Steamboat InnCarsethorn, DumfriesHidden in a rural corner of Dumfriesshire, The Steamboat Inn isnrsquot particularly well-known when it comes to Scottish scenic pubs.But it should be with its beer garden that sits right on the edge of a wonderfully quiet beach, the sea almost within touching distance of the tables. The pub is dog friendly too, and your canine companion will love running around on the sand while you sit back and enjoy the views of the Solway Firth.Covid safety precautions are taken seriously by the staff and, to top it all off, the food is delicious and offers great value for money.thesteamboatinn

title: five-things-east-lothian-bank-holiday-weekend
story: Remember, though, that coronavirus is still a risk, so make sure you socially distance and follow all the remaining regulations to keep yourself and other people safe.Heres five ideas of things to do in the county this weekend:. Go to the beachSeaclf BeachWe all know were spoilt for choice with beautul beaches in East Lothian. Why not pay a visit to the likes of Gullane Bents, Yellowcraig or Belhaven Bay to name just a few  Or what about Seaclf, which has been named one of the most popular to visit in the whole of the UK . Enjoy a walkTwin Law, Lammermuirs East Lothians great outdoors is far more than just beaches, though. We have some of the most spectacular countryside anywhere in Scotland. And with restrictions relaxed, were free to go and enjoy it! Why not enjoy a getaway in the peace of the Lammermuir Hills  A stretch of legs at Musselburgh Lagoons  Or enjoy a walk in one of the countys stunning woodlands, like Pressmennan or Butterdean  And thats just scratching the surface of all the great choices on your doorstep!. Visit Newhailes or Preston MillPreston MillThese two National Trust for Scotland properties reopened to visitors today . Why not pay one of them a visit  Newhailes in Musselburgh is a stunning th-century villa with extensive grounds, while Preston Mill, well-known to fans of the hit TV series Outlander, is a wonderful piece of county history. Youll find them in Musselburgh and East Linton respectively.. Get back in the pool or the gymThe months-long closure of the countys sports centres has been tough for many of us. But now, with restrictions relaxed, theyre back open again. Why not enjoy heading to your local swimming pool or gym again  Remember, though, that the pools in Musselburgh and North Berwick arent open just yet.. Enjoy a meal outCustomers enjoying a pint at the Ravelston House Hotel in MusselburghPubs and restaurants across the county are finally back open after whats been a very dficult few months for them. So why not go support them while at the same time enjoying some fantastic local food and drink  Remember to book ahead, though, and follow all social distancing measures to stay safe.

title: cafe-hairdresser-hollies-day-centre-musselburgh-reopening
story: Initially, the facilities will be open for three days, with the hairdresser open from .am to pm and the cafe opening its doors at am.The week after, they will open five days a week, at the same time.Liz Shannon, day centre manager, said: ldquoThe conditions are the same as before ndash entry is through the black gate on High Street. We have lsquotrack and tracersquo at the door as well as sanitiser. There have been changes put in place by the Government regarding track and trace so every inidual must be signed in. They should remember to have their phone number to hand.ldquoAll customers must wear a face covering until they sit at a table. Customers will leave by the front door, as before.ldquoCustomers for the hairdresser must use the chair lt in order to reduce the amount of sanitising to the building, for example the banister.ldquoThe cafe will be selling the usual menu, plus dinners.Liz said they were looking forward to reopening the centrersquos lunch club but added: ldquoWe are unable to open this until Government guidelines allow us to operate our bus.ldquoWe hope this will happen in the summer as we canrsquot wait to see all our members again.

title: new-community-orchard-created-musselburgh
story: A collection of  Scottish heritage apple saplings, some of the same ieties which were grown in an orchard at Pinkie House more than  years ago, have been planted in Lewisvale Park by Sustaining Musselburgh, a sub group of Musselburgh Area Partnership.Gaynor Allen, Sustaining Musselburgh chairperson, said: ldquoPlanting trees is a great way of investing in the future, it is good for the planet and good for the community.She added: ldquoPlanting apple trees will hopefully prove to have many more benefits, as it will provide free fruit, and we hope to engage with the whole community in an annual apple day once the trees are big enough to bear fruit.ldquoWe are very excited about this project and hope that schools and community groups will get involved.Musselburgh Area Partnership voted unanimously to support the project and hopes it will attract more people to Lewisvale Park.The partnership paid for  of the trees, which were planted by Andrew Hogarth, East Lothian Councilrsquos area amenities officer, and Tony Brunton, from the councilrsquos Musselburgh amenities team.Three of the trees in the orchard were donated by Art Walk Portyrsquos Neighbouring Orchard project, which gave out  trees for planting throughout Portobello, Musselburgh and Craigmillar.Iain Clark, Musselburgh Area Partnership chairman, said: ldquoMusselburgh Area Partnership is keen to support sustainability projects within our community.ldquoWith our new sustainability sub group and in partnership with our local amenity services, the planting of a new community orchard in Lewisvale Park will hopefully provide local focus on sustainable sources and provide the community with hopefully one of many natural resources.Over future years, Sustaining Musselburgh intends to add more fruit trees in the park and include pear, plum, hazelnut and walnut.Gaynor said: ldquoWe thought we would be lucky to begin with  trees, so we are delighted to have so many.ldquoWe intend to add more trees over the next few years.ldquoThis is a lovely project and we are delighted we were able to make it happen in the first year of Sustaining Musselburgh coming together.ldquoIt is fantastic to be a sub group of the area partnership and to work in partnership with other groups and organisations including Queen Margaret University.Sustaining Musselburgh is also working to get plastic free status for the town by encouraging organisations and people to get rid of single-use plastic, working with Musselburgh Active Toun, and working to bring a sustainability hub to the town.

title: fringe-sea-appoints-first-artist-residence
story: Fringe by the Sea  has chosen illustrator Eilidh Muldoon, who grew up in the town, to create visuals which will be displayed around North Berwick in the run-up to and during the festival.She will also be involved in the FBTS Art Club, launching on Saturday, May , with a live online event, giving residents the opportunity to create their own art and have it exhibited in the town.To sign up for the launch session, go to ctzn.tk ArtClubEilidh said: ldquoIrsquom thrilled to be the first-ever artist-in-residence for Fringe by the Sea, especially as North Berwick is my home town.ldquoIt was the nicest thing to be asked to do, since I know the town and can imagine the transformation thatrsquos going to take place.ldquoIrsquom very excited to be a part of it. Irsquoll be injecting some extra vibrancy into the festival experience for visitors to enjoy in August ndash expect bright bursts of colour and pattern! Wersquore also encouraging people to get creative as part of the FBTS Art Club.ldquoI canrsquot wait to see the pieces created and help select those for exhibition.Eilidh, , grew up on Old Abbey Road with sister Hannah and brother Dave, and attended Law Primary School and North Berwick High School.She now lives in Edinburgh with husband Bob and -month-old daughter Maisie.She studied illustration at Edinburgh College of Art and currently teaches part-time at the college, also running creative workshops and working freelance from her home.She has illustrated childrenrsquos books and is working on her first self-authored picture book.Rory Steel, Fringe by the Searsquos director, said: ldquoEilidhrsquos such an inspiration and itrsquos going to be a real pleasure working with her on the art club and other initiatives in the build-up to Augustrsquos extravaganza.Fringe by the Sea  will take place from August  to , using new spaces around the town to take into account Covid- protocols and guidance.See fringebythesea

title: longniddry-authors-book-delves-history-witchcraft-musselburgh
story: David Robertson, whose former research into the witchcraft of East Lothian was featured in his book Goodnight My Servants All, published in , found references in recently rediscovered trial records to th-century ldquoblack magic charms ndash which were actually pre-Reformation Christian prayers.David, , has combined the details of these previously unknown trials with other cases of Musselburgh witchcraft in his new book, A Calendar of Musselburgh Witchcraft.The Forthview Road resident said: ldquoThere were very few Musselburgh records in Register House, and they were supposed to have been lost, but a few years ago they were discovered in a locked room in the town hall in Musselburgh.ldquoThere was a real treasure trove of old burgh records, including two court books.The rediscovered records were moved to Haddingtonrsquos John Gray Centre, where David read through them to look for witchcraft trials.He found two cases, from , of young women named Jonet Little and Agnes Mitchell who were found guilty of witchcraft and sentenced to be strangled then burnt.David said: ldquoThat was the stock punishment for witchcraft. People run away with the idea that witches in Scotland were burnt alive but that is nonsense. They were strangled at the stake and then their corpse was burned.The records of their trial quoted the ldquodiabolic charms the women were said to have used ndash actually Catholic prayers.David said: ldquoThere were references to the Virgin Mary and to the saints and angels, which was not the sort of thing the new Protestant church in Scotland liked to hear about.ldquoThey thought these Catholic prayers were so beyond the pale they could be used to invoke the Devil. But I donrsquot think thatrsquos what the women who used them thought.But Davidrsquos book also seeks to point out that some of the women accused of witchcraft were not necessarily innocent of all crimes.He explained: ldquoObviously itrsquos a good thingpeople are trying to cure other people of illnesses and diseases, no matter how useless the cures may be.ldquoBut after all the research Irsquove done, I think at least some of these people were prepared to take on more dubious jobs.ldquoPeople would come to them for cures but sometimes people would come to them and ask to get rid of an unwanted husband or a sick child that had become a nuisance.ldquoWhile the majority of these professional healers was just what these women were, I do think there was at least the odd one that was prepared to take on a contract that was basically criminal.ldquoOne plant commonly used was foxglove leaves and the healer would use the phrase: lsquoThis will end or mend.rsquoA Calendar of Musselburgh Witchcraft is available via troubador bookshop history-politics-society a-calendar-of-musselburgh-witchcraft

title: chance-dedicate-book-baby-born-lockdown
story: Local libraries are hoping to see their Bookbug sessions ndash storytelling with parents and children aged up to five ndashin Bookbug Week in mid-May.And as part of the welcome back to parents and young children, a dedication service will see special messages and the name of babies born since March  placed in library books.Parents will be able to keep the book featuring their babyrsquos name as a memento, free of charge, once it is no longer available for loan.A library service spokesperson said: ldquoSupport from family and friends is so vital when you welcome a little one, and missing out on the lovely firsts that come from baby groups and meeting other families is a real loss. Wersquove missed seeing all of our Bookbug families but wersquove particularly missed welcoming little ones into their communities.To take part, email ypslibraries@eastlothian.gov.uk with the babyrsquos name and date of birth parent name and address.

title: speed-checks-carried-various-roads-haddington
story: Police have been using pop-up lsquoofficersrsquo at a iety of locations, including Haldane Avenue, West Road and Pencaitland Road, in a bid to influence driver behaviour.A spokesperson for Police Scotland said: ldquoThese have proven useful in deterring speeding and will be used in conjunction with real-time speed checks in the coming weeks.ldquoDrivers found to be exceeding the posted speed limit could be issued a fixed penalty ticket or reported to the Procurator Fiscal.

title: haddington-woman-pays-tribute-artist-father-passes-away
story: Rod McKie died in hospital in Edinburgh on March , aged , after a brain haemorrhage following a stroke.A cartoonist, his work was published in Playboy, The New Yorker and The Wall Street Journal.His daughter Kimberley Paton, who lives in Haddington with husband Edward, was among those paying tribute to the artist.She said: ldquoEvery single human being on the Earth, he would have loved you and been kind to you and treated you equally to him. He was very unique, very quirky, very fun and obsessed with Kate Bush.Kimberley said that his death came as the family, including mum Lis, sister Dominique and brother Anthony, were getting ready to celebrate five years of him being cancer-free, after having cancer of the larynx.The family launched a GoFundMe page to help with the costs of the funeral and to assist the family. Already, more than pound, has been raised.The artistrsquos brain will now be used in the Linchpin study, which aims to find out more about intracerebral brain haemorrhages.Kimberley told the Courier: ldquoRoddy was an amazing man and we were just completely unprepared for his passing.Donate via gofund.me ebebab

title: two-shetland-ponies-now-calling-north-berwick-law-home
story: They are the second pair in less than two months to join the ponies that live on the famous hill.The two Shetland ponies ldquomoved in at the beginning of the month and were introduced to help with grazing.Called Peanut and Minstrel, they bring the number of ponies on North Berwick Law to  the others are wild Exmoor ponies.Visitors are asked not to feed them as they have ldquoplenty of natural food.A Facebook page called lsquoNorth Berwick Poniesrsquo shares updates and pictures of the animals.

title: isle-may-reopens-visitors
story: Officially opened last Monday, the island ndashmanaged by nature agency NatureScot ndash will welcome wildle lovers arriving via the main operators, including North Berwickrsquos Scottish Seabird Centre RIB.David Steel, NatureScot manager, said: ldquoWe will be opening the nature reserve safely to the public so people can come see the thousands of nesting seabirds.ldquoWe encourage people to visit to experience the wild beauty of this east coast island, but also to do so safely by staying on designated paths.The reserve is home to more than , pairs of birds, including more than , puffins, and also one of the largest grey seal colonies in the UK. Access to the island is free, though there are boat charges to get there.

title: retired-minister-tells-history-haddingtons-churches-new-book
story: The Rev David Dutton spent more than two years piecing together the history of churches ndash from the past and present ndash throughout the town.Now, Singular Solace: An Ecclesiastical History of Haddington has been released online.The retired Church of Scotland minister traces the story of the churches in the burgh from Anglo-Saxon times through to the millennium.He said: ldquoThe wonderful thing about the history of the church in Haddington is its richness and iety.ldquoAlmost all of the main movements in the Scottish church, both before and after the Reformation, were present in the burgh.As well as telling the story of St Maryrsquos Parish Church, the -year-old traces the origins and development of  places of worship in the burgh, including Holy Trinity Scottish Episcopal Church, St Johnrsquos Free Church ndash which became Haddington West Parish Church ndash St Maryrsquos Roman Catholic Church, and several small, independent congregations.Mr Dutton said: ldquoI had done a Master of Theology degree in church history and the le and work of John Brown, the author of the Self-Interpreting Bible.ldquoIn the course of that, I came to realise there were all these other congregations in Haddington.ldquoFor obvious reasons, St Maryrsquos tends to hog the limelight but there are several others over the years.ldquoI think each of them has a wee story to tell.The book, which is available on Amazon Kindle, has its heroines and heroes, including Ada de Warenne, who founded the Cistercian Convent east of the town John Brown, minister of the Burgher Church, who is best known as the author of the Self-Interpreting Bible Joseph Mantica, who conducted a mission to the Roman Catholic community in East Lothian and Hilda Nimmo Smith, whose gt triggered the restoration of the east end of St Maryrsquos.It even has a villain: David Gellatly, minister of the Relief Church, who was found guilty of acts of deception, hood and flagrant immorality.David, who lives on Haddingtonrsquos Acredales, is also a member of the congregation at St Maryrsquos Parish Church.The former minister at the High Kirk in Stranraer also served as clerk to the Presbytery of Wigtown and Stranraer, and told the Courier: ldquoI hope my account will appeal to church folk and those interested in the history of Haddington.ldquoA number of people assisted my research by sharing their memories of work among children and young people in the s and s.ldquoI have published Singular Solace online so as to make it widely available during the pandemic.ldquoThe cost is only pound.

title: uk-supermarkets-issue-urgent-recalls-chocolate-meat-fruit-items
story: Food allergies, salmonella poisoning, Hepatitis A and chocking hazardsare just some of the reasons behind a number of urgent product recalls across the UK.Weve rounded up the latest products to be recalled.If you have bought any of the items mentioned below, you need to be aware of these possible health risks.Hotel Chocolat Summer Desserts SleeksterHotel Chocolat is recalling Summer Desserts Sleekster chocolates because they contain egg, wheat , hazelnutsand walnuts , which are not mentioned on the label.Product details:Summer Desserts SleeksterHoffmanrsquos Chopped HerringHoffmans Foods is recalling Chopped Herring because it contains egg and sulphites which are not mentioned on the label. This means the product is a possible health risk for anyone with an allergy or intolerance to egg and or a sensitivity to sulphur dioxide and or sulphites.Product details:Hoffmanrsquos Chopped HerringPresident Mini Cheese SelectionLactalis McLelland Ltd is recalling its President Mini Cheese Selection because it may contain nuts which is not mentioned on the label.
